Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Soft Materials at Penn State
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This award supports the renewal of the Soft Materials REU at Penn State. A project-centered and team-oriented educational and research program is proposed to complement the training of a new generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers capable of crossing traditional academic boundaries. This REU in Soft Materials will continue to train undergraduate students with knowledge, perspective, and teamwork experience to inspire them to become Ph.D. candidates in Engineering and Sciences. Undergraduate students across Materials Science, Chemical Engineering, Energy Engineering and Chemistry will be trained in research areas organized around three themes: ion conduction in ion-containing polymers, biomaterials including function of biomacromolecules and self-assembled bio-structures, and thermodynamics and transport in polymer mixtures.
The overarching theme of this REU is the study and development of novel soft materials. Specific objectives are to: 1) Provide students with hands-on experience on a variety of sophisticated analytical, (nano) fabrication, and computational techniques, while working in a project-centered collaborative research environment. 2) Produce a cadre of future scientists and engineers who have the ability to contribute across traditional disciplines and appreciate the wide-ranging scientific and engineering issues related to soft materials. REU students will participate in general activities, such as career development seminars, several social activities, and the final symposium. The REU program is envisioned as nucleating a "center-of-excellence for undergraduate research" in the field of soft materials, while considerably strengthening the education and research experience of our future materials leaders. We anticipate that more than 50 undergraduate students will participate over the three years of the program.
This REU Site is funded by the NSF Division of Materials Research.
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The REU in Soft Materials at Penn State will provide the scientific training for the generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers capable of crossing traditional academic boundaries. A special emphasis on outreach to individuals from under represented groups (such as women, Hispanics and African Americans) and persons with disabilities will be pursued, with the intent of attracting them to scientific/engineering careers. The program will train undergraduate students with knowledge, perspective, and teamwork experience to inspire them to become Ph.D. candidates in Engineering and Sciences. Research is organized around polymers, biological macromolecules and self-assembled bio-structures which have potential use in pharmaceutical, agricultural and other industries. Additionally, REU students will participate in general activities, such as career development seminars, several social activities, and the final symposium. Finally, graduate (as mentors) and undergraduate students will actively participate in the design and performance of experiments (including virtual experiments), and they will benefit from the interaction and immersion in a global collaborative research with international peers that complement the intensive training in theory, simulation, and/or experiment that they receive at their US home institutions. The REU program is envisioned as nucleating a "center-of-excellence for undergraduate research" in the field of soft materials, while considerably strengthening the education and research experience of our future materials leaders. We anticipate that more than 50 undergraduate students will participate over the three years of the program.
This REU Site is funded by the NSF Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Penn State (PSU), has a long history of sustained contributions to materials science and strong institutional support to foster efforts in soft materials. The REU in Soft Materials coordinated activities with the directors of other REU programs at Penn State (including the Physics Labs REU program, Chemistry and Chemical Engineering). REU students from those programs participated in several social activities and the final Penn State Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) REU symposium. This Symposium is a cornerstone of the REU programs at Penn State, and the REU in Soft Material proudly catalyzed this, joining the REU in Physics, during its first year back in 2007. During the last years, the Symposium hosted over 100 undergraduate students’ and teacher’s presentations.

The overarching theme of this REU was the study and development of novel soft materials. Our specific objectives were to 1) Provide students with hands-on experience in a variety of sophisticated analytical, (nano) fabrication, and computational techniques, while working in a project-centered collaborative research environment; and 2) Produce a cadre of future scientists and engineers who have the ability to contribute across traditional disciplines and appreciate the wide-ranging scientific and engineering issues related to soft materials.

The program provided undergraduate students with the knowledge, perspective, and teamwork experiences to inspire them to become Ph.D. candidates in engineering and sciences. Additionally, during the seven years that the program lasted the REU students participated in general activities, such as career development seminars, several social activities, and the final symposium. Graduate students (as mentors) and undergraduate students actively participated in the design and performance of experiments (including virtual experiments), and they benefited from the interaction and immersion in a global research arena that complemented the intensive training in theory, simulation, and/or experiment that they received at their home institutions. The REU program was envisioned as nucleating a "center-of-excellence for undergraduate research" in the field of soft materials, while considerably strengthening the education and research experience of our future materials leaders. Initially, we anticipated that more than 90 undergraduate students would participate over the six years of the program (with 60 fully supported by NSF.) During the funding cycles we were able to have 108 participants, due to the high leverage from PSU and other resources.

A major aim of NSF programs is to contribute to the human-resource base for science and technology, and the REU programs are a capstone of this aim.  The REU in Soft Materials at PSU contributed to this goal through the training of undergraduate students with the knowledge, perspective, and teamwork experience to inspire them to become Ph.D. candidates in engineering and sciences. During our funding cycles, we provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas to a diverse group of 108 undergraduate students and over 50 graduate mentors and postdocs that included women, African American, Native American, Latino/Hispanic American, and international students among others. Fostering the integrative education and training of students across Materials Science, Chemical Engineering, and Chemistry, the central goal of this REU.

The major elements of the proposed project were training undergraduate students and inspiring them to become Ph.D. candidates in Engineering and Sciences. Students integrated their research in an energetic environment through continuous communication with their counterparts, through meetings, seminars, and web-based documents.  Each year of this REU, undergraduate students spent nine weeks in the laboratories of the PSU faculty mentors. Each undergraduate student undertook research projects, training sessions, and social activities. We believe that these experiences created individuals with the broad skill-set needed to have an immediate impact in both academia and the US in general.  These REU research projects allowed these newborn researchers to work in internationally recognized research groups and interact with young and senior scientists. The Ph.D. mentor students learned and applied mentoring techniques that they will integrate into their own future research group.  This cross-fertilization extends the faculty mentor’s ability to train undergraduate and graduate students for future employment in a global, academic and technical arena.  In short, undergraduate and graduate students gained experience in different research techniques for advanced soft materials, actively participated in the design and performance of experiments (or virtual experiments), and benefited from the interaction and immersion in global collaborative research with international experts.  Our goal was for this experience to ignite their search for intensive graduate-level training and thus encourage them to pursue a Ph. D. in Sciences and Engineering. We are glad to report we were successful in achieving this goal! Since over 85% o the REU students are pursuing or planning to pursue graduate studies.
